response.answer_text: Suppose everyone realised that our society is transient. That at some point in the slider of time, if we look back far enough we simply do not exist. And further on, at some point, we also are all gone. Meaning is devoid. Progress is laughable. All and any achievements we attain will be forgotten. If this was universally realised, then suicide is the logical option. Another way to understand this point is through Carl Sagan's reflections on the Little Blue Spot we call Earth. "you see a dot. That's here. That's home. That's us. On it, everyone you ever heard of, every human being who ever lived, lived out their lives. The aggregate of all our joys and sufferings, thousands of confident religions, ideologies and economic doctrines, every hunter and forager, every hero and coward, every creator and destroyer of civilizations, every king and peasant, every young couple in love, every hopeful child, every mother and father, every inventor and explorer, every teacher of morals, every corrupt politician, every superstar, every supreme leader, every saint and sinner in the history of our species, lived there – on a mote of dust, suspended in a sunbeam. The earth is a very small stage in a vast cosmic arena. Think of the rivers of blood spilled by all those generals and emperors so that in glory and in triumph they could become the momentary masters of a fraction of a dot. Think of the endless cruelties visited by the inhabitants of one corner of the dot on scarcely distinguishable inhabitants of some other corner of the dot. How frequent their misunderstandings, how eager they are to kill one another, how fervent their hatreds. Our posturings, our imagined self-importance, the delusion that we have some privileged position in the universe, are challenged by this point of pale light."

If you knew that reckless scientists were inevitably going to create a chemical chain reaction that was going to destroy the planet unless you released an air-borne illness that would kill all humans before they did, what would you do? Knowledge is dangerous, but it can save that which it does not kill.

Hell yeah. E=mc2 is an example. It looks like five random characters next to each other. However, thousands of people lost their lives to it. Oh yeah. I wonder if you can kill someone with Pythagoras' theorem: a2+b2=c2. Knowledge can create.Knowledge can destroy. I guess that's the beauty of it.
Not knowledge per se but bad judgment in how to apply it.
